commentBody: After a week of snails I finally get a blue lightning bolt.  This seemed easy by comparison, seven and change‚Ä¶
I hope everyone will be speeding through the wide open spaces in the grid. Take no prisoners? This puzzle? I hope not. With this one, everyone should have a fairy tale ending. A romp.
I just want to hear Deb‚Äôs pirate accent.

Wow that went quickly. For some reason, I seemed to be on the right wavelength for this puzzle.  Even though it was a quick solve for me, I liked it as it didn't have a lot of emus.  The fill really helped with the long entries. This was fun.

Just about right. Had to jump about a bit, make a few guesses some of which were wrong which made it interesting. Enjoyed the clues for BINGOPARLOR and EMMA. Please don‚Äôt remind me about Kate MARA now that we have Jessica Kirby as the ultimate Invisible Woman. And for God sake don‚Äôt remind this Cincinnatian about the LARAMs!!!

When I RAISEdTHECURTAIN on this puzzle I thought I was in for a tough ride, but I HAdAT it and decided to TAKENOPRISONERS. My tactical approach was to REVERSEENGINEER the puzzle by working from the middle downward and finally to the top.  Voila, a FAIRYTALEENDING. I liked the way the long spanners revealed themselves without being too obvious.

I also liked learning about SAMUELCHASE, an interesting historical precedent.

If you want to trigger a farmer, call them ‚ÄúOREO cows‚Äù

They‚Äôre belted galloways!

- Signed, an American who has on numerous occasions annoyed her farmer Kiwi husband with calling them OREO cows
Houston, no problem at all.
Who is Eli Clinton? Neither Mr. Google nor Mr. Wikipedia have anything about such a person of any renown.
The best OREO clue in a very long time!

Ended up having to guess letters for the cross between NOOR and NACRE but such is life. Otherwise fairly straightforward. 

I did like OSTENTATION, though. New one for me.

Enjoyed it enormously - there is such a charge when I spot what a grid spanning answer it. Personal fave was a FAIRYTALEENDING

Tried the new domino game. Meh - all those years of matching end pieces with family and friends means this doesn‚Äôt work for me. It‚Äôs a maths based problem packaged in a familiar form. I love me maths based games (when is the NYT gonna give us Killer Sudoku??) but these just doesn‚Äôt work for me.

Now this is a puzzle!
A very welcomed enjoyable solve with a good fil and clever clues; unlike yesterdays debacle

Very briefly intimidating and then almost immediately easy to complete.  Very straightforward Q&A and simple to do.  But I still enjoyed the experience.  I'm wondering if I had it unusually well in hand, or if it was just an easier Friday than normal.

It almost always turns out to be the latter....

I reckon, like me, a lot of fellow solvers dropped an N in square 44 as their last letter to fall. 

Mother of pearl! That cross was a toughie.

That little alphabet run aside, today‚Äôs puzzle was *much* kinder to me than yesterday‚Äôs.  But I enjoyed them both.
That was the easiest Friday in a while!

Strangely enough I was able to intuit most of the puzzle spanners with very few crossings, making this a pretty easy Friday solve. Maybe OREO should be banned, at least from late week puzzles? No matter how fresh the clue, it's still too obvious. Four letters? Black and white? What else could it be?

Nice grid but too easy.

5/10
My initial guess for 10D [Where many gather to form a line?] was a television "writers RoOm" which I thought was brilliant! Alas, it was wrong. LOL
I just wasn‚Äôt in the right frame of mind for this puzzle. More experienced players seem to be zipping through it. Oh well, there‚Äôs always tomorrow.

"Are you buying those drapes?"
"I'm all but curtain of it."

(These puns make me shutter.)

On Wednesday I was stumped because I was 100% sure that the gas brand was SoNOCO and I didn't remember the T-Rex named SUE.  I did eventually google the answer and filled it in, but I was upset with myself because I had felt too much pressure about maintaining my streak and I had decided that if I ever couldn't finish a puzzle without any lookups, I would just let the streak go.  Like with connections, I never worry about my streak, I just do the puzzles when I can - sometimes catching up after several days. 

So on Thursday, I decided to stick to my word (to myself) and fall on my sword.  I left the top-left square empty and after completing the rest of the puzzle, I finished by revealing the puzzle.

Previous streak: 533 (though really 532 with no lookups).  Current streak: 1 üòä

The "unakyu" part of 32D had a very Japanese look to it, but it wasn't a word I had seen before. But then 32D gradually changed from ___ to _E_ to EE_, and I realized the first part of the word was "unagi" with the "gi" chopped off. I haven't figured out the "kyu" (likely "kyuu") part yet, Japanese is full of "kyuu"s. Maybe in the morning.

Absolutely loved this. What fun with so many long words!

Enjoyable, even though I usually prefer themes.

No cakewalk for me, but I got there in the end (and I‚Äôll admit to looking up the Jordan queen, which I‚Äôll remember someday, for my final letter).

For 56 across I originally had ‚Äúgo for the jugular,‚Äù which I was quite pleased with. Then I realized other idioms fit, too, which in a difficult puzzle really ‚Äúhit where it hurts.‚Äù
That‚Äôs two Fridays in a row for Samuel Chase.

This puzzle proves you don't have to actually know much to finish without lookups. Examples: 

SAMUELCHASE: I got Chase from the crosses (remembered NACRE from previous puzzles) and then had to come up with a first name. Asked myself what a good first name starting with S for a founding father might be and tried Samuel. Ding ding ding!

VIOL: Originally had lute, which worked when I had roe instead of EEL, rune instead of EMMA (People cast runes, right? And they can be made out of stone?), and SUV instead of GMC. Once I tried the only other 3-letter sushi word I could think of, that section fell into place and I crossed my fingers that VIOL was a thing.

ADAPTOR: Did not know this British spelling, although with the overseas clue, it makes sense. It couldn't be ADAPTeR because then what's an eSTENTATION? 

LARAM and OMANI: These were the last ones to fall for me. Had tapINTO and diGINTO for 24A, but neither of those was giving me anything that looked like a football team. Finally realized that iMANI should have been OMANI, which led to LOG INTO.  But still, where the heck is Laram? So after finishing the puzzle, I Googled "who won Superbowl 56" and slapped my head.  What's that term we use for mis-parsing an answer?

And did anyone else think the 6D clue referred to the TV network before realizing it was more straightforward than that? Sometimes a peacock is just a peacock.

I was pleased that I remembered the name of the Queen of Jordan. A few minutes later my little bubble was burst when the crossings reminded me that it was spelled NOOR, not NOIR.
Interesting, "noor" means light and "noir" means black.

A bit tough, and didn't have much to start with, so started down the grid and found some possible answers, continued and had more success at the bottom and worked my way back up to finish out.

Good one, Gia, keep working on that cycle.
For a little while I thought I‚Äôd learned something new and interesting about SAMUELadAms.

never had a question before about the mini.
can someone let me in on the significance of the circles today?
I would have preferred a reference to two ELIS who actually were admitted on the basis of merit - instead of just one.

Delightful.
Some cultural references held me up:
I did reveal the LA RAMS which I would never have guessed, even with some letters, not knowing AMANDA either. PLEDGES was similarly opaque.

GMC isn't our General Medical Council, so looked that one up; the only mysteries to me now are ELOISE and ROTH - help please!

Can't believe I finished this one, and under my average to boot.   Took me forever to get a toehold, which was finally achieved at a PRO/ARISE.   Slowly chopped away from there, and then ReverseEngineer Donnelly came to me and started to open things up.    Some really tough answers:  Ostentation (which I didn't even know was a weird), End use, Arfs, and Undeviating were all ones that I needed *lots* of crosses to solve.  Neither Eloise nor Cabello are familiar to me either.   Favorite clue:  57A Brothers-To-Be

This took me an age, but I got there in the end. 

I just don't get 37A. Are there such things as ant traps? ü§î

Is it me or is it the puzzle? I would not describe this puzzle as being in my wheelhouse yet I completed it in 17% less time than my average. Perhaps even after solving crosswords steadily for the last six years, I'm still improving my skills.
Whoo‚Äîfast and fun. A ROMP.

I thought I was off to an all time great start when I got REVERSEENGINEER without the help of a single cross, and then nailed the gimme right under it which I was sure was winwinsituation. When the crosses indicated that at least one of them was wrong I came back down to earth, but I finished well below my Friday average.
Still I enjoyed that brief moment and the delusions of adequacy that accompanied it. Oh well‚Ä¶

Stray, sleep-deprived thoughts:

‚Ä¢I found the juxtaposition of a clue referencing George W. Bush and the answers elsewhere READ TO and PET GOAT darkly amusing. (Although I actually think the flak W got for that classroom video was rather unfair; bolting out wouldn‚Äôt have actually changed anything other than alarming a bunch of kids. In fact, the world would surely be a far better place today if he‚Äôd spent the entire rest of his presidency just doing readings in front of children and launching PEPFAR. It‚Äôs still funny to watch, though.) I wonder if this was intentional.
‚Ä¢I‚Äôm surprised so many people had trouble with NOOR. Even if you didn‚Äôt know NACRE, I think it‚Äôs a fairly common feminine Arabic name (admittedly, judging mostly from characters in works of fiction on my part).
‚Ä¢I must have spent a full third of my solve time on the area around LA RAM. It seems the NFL is the area of sportsball I‚Äôm the most clueless about; I‚Äôm not even sure if I‚Äôd ever heard of the team before. (At least with with college sports you can often guess a university name without any specific knowledge of their programs that presumably exist to give med students CTE case studies.) Also, am I missing something, or is ANT for 37A an example of what we call in solver jargon ‚Äúgreen paint‚Äù?
‚Ä¢I think REVERSE ENGINEER was the first time I‚Äôve ever had a spanner as my very first answer filled in; the others required a few crossings and some pondering, so still some nice crunch elsewhere.

Fun puzzle overall.
Kite flying is difficult in MISTY weather also....

I‚Äôm not a novice solver, but I can still relate to Deb‚Äôs advice to them‚Ä¶ and urge them to take heart! This one was still intimidating to me at first‚Äîand even second‚Äîglance, yet it ended up being one of my faster solves. Once you find a foothold you can usually just keep going, letter by letter, word by word. Such a satisfying feeling to find you‚Äôve filled in all that white space!
Enjoyable puzzle. Found the last two a bit gimmicky for my taste so this was a return to form

As so often happens, I started at the very bottom and worked my way up. Some gimmees that helped were ELOISE, NOOR and NACRE. Then got stuck at the very top three rows. All it took, though, was to walk away from the puzzle to get something out out of a cabinet - not more than 15 seconds - and when I got back to the puzzle on my kitchen counter, it was as if the answers had miraculously filled themselves in. Thanks to a few early crosses, that is. Good workout.

Hah!  Every time I see ENDUSE in the grid it looks like a single word.  I can‚Äôt think of a good definition for it ‚Äì can someone help me out here?  I am endusiastic about this word!  @Mike?  Anyone?

Color in the box today ‚Äì that gorgeous stack of REVERSE ENGINEER / FAIRY TALE ENDING, bolstered by RAISE THE CURTAIN and TAKE NO PRISONERS.  Answers like this lift a puzzle beyond simply filling in the boxes, beyond simply cracking clues.

Freshness as well, for spark.  That brand-new clue for OREO, which has appeared more than 500 times in the Times puzzle, and along comes this terrific debut cow clue!  Freshness from 13 answers seen three times or less in the 80+ years of this puzzle.

Add a bit of adorability with ARFS and PET GOAT, mix in a bit of class with OSTENTATION and UNDEVIATING, and, for me, this was feel-good on top of a fun fill-in that included areas of rub on one hand, and on the other, ‚ÄúWhee!‚Äù areas where answers cascaded in a splat.

Stellar and day-brightening ‚Äì a gift.  Thank you, Gia.  Your puzzles have shown that you‚Äôve got the knack, and I look forward to unwrapping more!

Whew. Typical tough Friday for me, but ended up being an enjoyable workout. None of the grid spanners coming to me just from the clues, but that just meant a bunch of nice 'aha' moments when they finally dawned on me with some crosses. 

Three debut answers in this one, but each of them quite familiar terms. A bit surprised at that. Pretty amazing feat of construction. 

Puzzle find today I'll put in a reply. 

...

Didn‚Äôt get the happy music, everything looks right. How is ORGS a non so conservative party (14d)? 

Everything else looks right, but my streak is threatened

What a fantastic Friday ROMP! I started last night and finished up this morning. My gimmes in this one were AMANDA Gorman, ELOISE at the Plaza, and Queen NOOR. I got the chance to meet Queen NOOR at one of the CA Governor‚Äôs Conference for Women when Maria Shriver was our First Lady. They were both lovely and gracious women. I also was familiar with ‚ÄúOREO‚Äù cows as I saw them on many road trips while living in Texas. The grid spanners were so satisfying as well. Thank you, Gia. Keep them coming and I hope you hit the cycle!

Since there‚Äôs no forum for the Mini ‚Ä¶
I solved the puzzle, but could someone please explain what‚Äôs happening in the grid at the end or what the circled letters mean? I don‚Äôt get it.

Note: There may be SPOILERS in the replies.
Funny that I was briefly stumped by OREO cow. I knew very well that the bovine described was a Belted Galloway, but that didn't quite fit. The "Duh!" moment came after, I think, one crossing letter.

Whoever it was in these pages said ‚ÄúThis is a great place to learn new things‚Äù really got it right.  Rabbit  hole today:  ‚Ä¶PARLOR.
Does it not often convey something unsavory, salacious, or at least indulgent?
My first thought on seeing that the puzzle needed a type ending in ‚ÄúO‚Äù was to try to squeeze in ‚ÄúTattoo.‚Äù 

But here are some others: 
Ice cream
Pizza
Bar (in UK?)
Suntan
Love
Sex

And don‚Äôt forget ‚Äúparlor trick.‚Äù

So the word derived from the place where talking, perhaps unreserved, is indulged in, becomes associated with other less-socially-sanctioned activities.  

Name me one type of ‚Äúparlor‚Äù that‚Äôs not just one cut above a ‚Äúden‚Äù!

I try to explain to non-solving friends and family the pure pleasure I get in seeing two long, totally unrelated and somewhat odd phrases (like 15A and 17A) piled on each other, and still all the crosses form legitimate words. 

Anyway, people here get it.

This one seemed like a themeless Tuesday puzzle to me. 

Just kidding. This was a solid Friday workout. Struggled more than usual to decipher the top three spanners. The bottom two came easily. Was unfamiliar with CABELLO, AMANDA, ELOISE and MARA, but these came readily enough from the crosses. "Magnet" rather than CATNIP for "Something very attractive" and ADAPTeR instead of ADAPTOR slowed me down. All the long entries were nice, but HASAT, GAPESAT, READTO and LARAM weren't. All in all, a good Friday challenge. Solved it unaided, but took almost 36 minutes.
Yep, liked this one a lot. Thanks Gia!

Slightly breezy Friday for me, as I solved at around 40 percent under my average time. I enjoyed the long fills‚Ä¶however (and this may be only me, and is not a complaint or even a nit), I‚Äôd always heard it as lift THE CURTAIN in that context so it took me half a moment to get RAISE since it didn‚Äôt come automatically. Anyone else?

I felt a twinge of sadness at 31A, AMANDA Gorman, as it sent me back to January 20, 2021, and her recitation of her moving poem, as I was thinking then that we‚Äôd survived the madness and were on the other side. Foolish, naive me.

A tough but fair Friday offering. I certainly found this smoother than the last few days, despite a good chunk of unknowns.
REVERSE ENGINEERING gave me a good start, as did some of the names; both AMANDA and Queen NOOR were gimmes. I remember watching that young lady at Pres Biden‚Äôs inauguration and being blown away by her talent and confidence. Made me go look up more of her work.  
Took several attempts to spell CABELLO using crosses. I knew who she was, just not sure of her surname.
ROTH and ANT trap threw me, but you all have kindly answered my fellow Brits queries. Always something new to learn.

Do the OREO cows come with cookie dispensers to dip in freshly squeezed milk?? Asking for a friend. Might make my Alpacas up their game as I‚Äôve had to discard the ruined fleeces for this year.

I learned that fact about SAMUEL CHASE just a week ago, when I thought he was the guy on the $10,000 bill. (It was Salmon.) So that was a big help. On the other hand, the last time I heard the national anthem of SPAIN, Fernando Alonso had just won a Formula 1 race. That was quite a long time ago, and I didn't remember that he was not singing along. Syria made more sense to me, but I've never heard that anthem. (They never win anything.)
What a great puzzle! So much fun. Loved the spans. Did pretty ok for me for a Friday. Only looked up a couple of names. Thanks so much, Gia!

This Friday felt much more accessible to me and ironically that resulted in a longer time‚Ä¶ I find that when I can actually slowly chip away at a late week puzzle then my end time is longer because I can go much longer before relying on the auto check setting to help. I got a good 2/3 of this puzzle filled in correctly before my first puzzle check, which almost never happens on a Fri/Sat/Sun. I don‚Äôt know if this puzzle was just well clued or if I‚Äôm getting better at solving or the topics are more in my wheelhouse (likely a combo of the three) but hey I‚Äôll take a longer solve time for a more fun and (personally) successful fill.
This puzzle took no prisoners but had a fairy tale ending. Merci, Gia!

Deb:
You're Sooo old-school!
You looked through all 506 "OREO" answers to see if the clue had ever referred to a cattle hide pattern, and found "none"

I used the AI program "Perplixity" that question, and in five seconds it came back with the same finding: 506 NYT "OREO" answers and none of a bovine persuasion.

Queen NOOR led me into the puzzle, but I was fixated on NBC's Peacock so I had ????STATION.  If only (famous last words) IF ONLY I had looked at ALL of the crossings, I could have saved myself from further embarrassment, but after my difficulty with the last two days of puzzles, what's one more Fail?  So, 2 wrong letters before I gave up.  Just don't have the time to devout to more puzzlement.  (What happened to "Leisurely Retirement"???

Most of my (once meager) savings is in ROTH IRAS....hallelujah!  After the Ohio state teachers' retirement fund went bankrupt for the 4th time (some decades ago, don't panic!) and I was for some years Not Employed (medical disasters cost more than money) the chance to put the funds into an IRA, and later to roll it into the ROTH IRA.  Even with the "required annual distribution" I'm doing better...  I hope it's safe from the chain saws!
Nicely put together puzzle, the long entries really were fun!
It‚Äôs    Salmon   Chase not  Samuel

Loved the long entries! And TIL there are currently no lyrics to Spain's national anthem. From the video linked below I learned that Franco enforced some lyrics during his reign but they were later dropped. https://youtu.be/X7yNKFqTqt8?si=KL-wbXH860Fs7IiU
Stayed with IRK waaay too long for 5D. Once I fixed that one, everything fell together quite nicely. Fun Friday!
In today's Mini, a Southern accent has a drawl, not a twang.  Texans have a twang.
Perfect Friday level challenge. Thank you!
One of the best puzzles in a long while. Loved all the long entries, and the shorter entries were unique and well clued. Can we do this every Friday?
Really liked this one! Enough of a challenge that I had to jump around the grid to find a foothold but once I did it was a pretty steady solve. Got the gold star in 8:38
Pretty easy for a Friday.  Near record time.  That said, loved both the clues and the solutions.

Some of us are old enough to remember when the stereotypical fairytale ending was "And those who survived lived miserably ever after." Not sure how many of us would call that "ideal".

Loved all the great longs in this!

Having mastered chess-boxing, I recently took up bingo-parkor(I don't use the British spelting).

One more late puzzle find. NEVER seen another one like this. Thought it was quite clever. Anyway - a Friday from March 13, 1992 (Friday the 13th?). Three 15 letter theme answers. None of them had any clue. See if you can figure this out. 17a. TARKINGTONNOVEL 36A. EIGHTEENDOUBLED 55A. LEGALSPEEDLIMIT Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=3/13/1992&g=36&d=A ....
Shouldn't that be computer mouses? Might be an error in the puzzle and writeup about it.
I absolutely loved this puzzle!!! Great/unique clues, great answers and wonderful spanning entries. This is why I like crosswords !
For the Mini Puzzle, what was the point of the unusual grid and what was the point of the circled letters?

Great puzzle! I'm having fun pursuing my streak which started on August 1. Coming into today at 21 and despaired of getting to 22. Bit by bit it came together. I told myself the time did not matter. What mattered was finishing the puzzle which I did in slightly above average so that's OK. proud as a peacock (peahen?) to get to 22. Glad to have people I can share puzzling with. Never heard Havana which is now my ear worm. (thanks a lot Deb! Ha ha) very catchy tune. Have a great day all.
Many people, including me, could not open today‚Äôs puzzle (August 22, 2025) on our cellphones.
Everyone must be in a great Friday mood because no one is talking about ADAPTOR vs ADAPTER .. lol fun puzzle :) love REVERSE ENGINEER

Will everyone see the same ads if they click on the Camila Cabello video in today's column?

I honestly do not want to spark a political debate here.

The ad in question cannot in good faith be described as non-controversial, regardless of your beliefs. It might be a real ad, but it could conceivably be satire from either side.

Let me know if you're seeing the same ad, without any comments likely to cause this thread to be removed, please.

Yes, this is vague. But if you see it, you'll know.
Really enjoyable themeless puzzle, nearly every clue seemed to click with me. Good stuff, Gia!

After a less than fun week for me I thoroughly enjoyed this one. Took a lot longer than my average Fri but it was challenging in a good way, nothing unfair and very satisfying solve. Some really nice wordplay and cluing, especially enjoyed the clues for EMMA and ORGY. Great work
Loved the clue for EMMA.

That was a fun puzzle, classic Friday difficulty that seems impenetrable at first but then starts coming together smoothly after you fill in a few minutes key words. I'll admit to being thrown off by ADAPTOR with an O, though, I was so certain it had an E that I had to look up the solution to finish off the puzzle. I should've known that the crossing was OSTENTATION, but I just assumed it starting with an E was a term I'd never heard of. Oh well, I got an interesting read about regional spelling variants out of the whole thing, at least.
18:08 today, I think  my fastest for a Friday. I really lucked out with correct initial guesses to some of the longer clues, and CABELLO got me started pretty nicely on the rest of the grid.
Nice pairing of Lent and Orgy!
People talk about stacks... I see LENT next to ORGY
Was fun slammin' those spanners.  Well done.

Well, I was hoping to find a cover of "Havana" performed on VIOLa da gamba, but no luck--lots of versions for modern strings, though. What's the matter, you "historically informed performers" too good for Ms. Cabello? So the best I can offer is some follies from the land of wordless anthems, played by an all-star cast, led by Jodi Savall: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5Frq7rjEGzs&list=RD5Frq7rjEGzs&start_radio=1
that was fun!  it's rude calling peacocks ostentatious however they're just showing their true colors much better clue 'bird showing it's true colors' people are ostentatious NOT animals
The puzzle was fine and I enjoyed it. But what needs to be commented on is that there were two minis today! Two!!!
Was stumped for a long time on 16D but finally ELIS was the only possibility based on the crosses so I put in the I for a satisfying solve!

Such a fun puzzle! Loved seeing all the illustrious women in the grid! That includes the AUNTS -- or ANT as it's often pronounced in these parts -- of which I am one. (There were a few men, too, of course. HAN Solo and SAMUEL CHASE, ELI, and if we women have the aunties, those boys have the PLEDGES.)

In fact, the first fill of which I was 100% certain was all the way at 39A, with Miss ELOISE. I knew [Camila] has an alliterative name, but hesitated with the spelling... 

I see I wasn't the only one falling for the capital misdirection with the [Peacock]! I even had _TATION filled from crosses and could not get past "station". Might've helped if I was into sitcoms more! Oy. 

And with that, I'm off to go be a good auntie and meet up with my niece. Enjoying a sunny and pleasant Friday afternoon and wish the same to all of you!
90 minutes.  Ugh Cnet held me up
Never heard of an Oreo cow, but there is a breed called a Belted Galloway that is black with a white belt around the middle.  My uncle calls them ‚Äúcop car cows‚Äù.
Fully thought SOS meant "save our souls" üòÖ

Yes, I loved those nice long entries! I always find the very long ones and the very short ones the easiest to get. I can't get middle-length words for the life of me.
Thanks Gia!

Ah - one more late puzzle find. Another quite unusual theme. I'll re-post this one tomorrow. Anyway... a Monday from April 20, 2015 by Tom McCoy. Some theme clues and answers: "Classic learning-to-read series (hint: 59-Across)" JANEANDDICK "Grimm fairy tale (hint: 59-Across)" GRETELANDHANSEL And the other two theme answers - straightforwardly clued with the same hint: MARYANDWILLIAM JULIETANDROMEO And 59 across: LADIESFIRST Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/20/2015&g=23&d=A ...

I thought this was going to be a streak breaker at first with all of those long entries but turned out to be smooth sailing, well below my Friday average time. I usually like to hit all the across clues first, followed by all of the downs, and then skip around from there. Fairly anal retentive about that lol, but I have my routine! Anyway, after hitting 15 across, I knew that would be frustrating, so went for the downs. With just a few short easy ones, those 15-word across answers became pretty obvious - it's amazing how much the NYT Crossword can be like playing Wheel of Fortune even though I'm a big fan of the former, not so much of the latter!
A quick fill but it was a delightful. Probably didn't take prisoners...

Very quick one today, about half my usual Friday length. But my times were all over the place this week, with Tuesday more like my usual Friday, Friday more like my usual Tuesday, and Thursday more like not anything, even longer than my usual Sundays.

I have no explanation. Except that I've been dealing with noisy data in my professional life. Not sure why the two would correlate, but there you have it.

Happy weekend!

I used to dread Friday and Saturday themeless puzzles because of their difficulty, and it would take me AGES to complete them. Two years into daily solving, and I now look forward to them. Sticking with it pays off! 

Loved the spanners in this one. Thanks to the creator and editors for a great start to the weekend!

This one was really satisfying.
I do the later week puzzles quite methodically: all the acrosses and then all the downs.
By the time I'd finished the acrosses I had almost nothing filled in, and I wasn't sure about most of the ones I had. The only one I was REALLY sure about was lute for 38A (ha!)
Then I went to the downs and got a few more. From there it was all about using what I'd got and fill in more and more.
A fair bit of US knowledge here (which might explain some of the discrepancy in the comments about this one), but nothing that couldn't be worked through with crosses.
I did have to look up NOOR though with it crossing with ROTH. Didn't help me that I had dACRE for the inlay.

But yes, overall a great crossword experience!

I also thought 10D was going to be about conga lines. I had NG and PARLOR and thought, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never heard of a Conga Parlor.‚Äù Ha. 

Fun puzzle!

@Barry Ancona

Interesting. Of the Fridays this month (there have been 4 puzzles)  today‚Äôs solve was my slowest by far. 
But all them quick by my normal standards. 

I struggled with the aforementioned, FAIRYTALEENDING.  I just could not stop thinking about a  negotiation-type of ‚Äòresolution.‚Äô  

I did think it a good Friday though.

@Weak
I even put in WINWIN at the start. Then had STORY instead of FAIRY.

@Dardanus
Elihu Yale was not the founder, he donated lots of money in 1718 so they renamed the college for him. 
From Wikipedia:
 In 1718, at the behest of either Rector Samuel Andrew or the colony's Governor Gurdon Saltonstall, Cotton Mather contacted the Boston-born businessman Elihu Yale to ask for money to construct a new building for the college. Through the persuasion of Jeremiah Dummer, Yale, who had made a fortune in Madras while working for the East India Company as the first president of Fort St. George, donated nine bales of goods, which were sold for more than ¬£560, a substantial sum of money. Cotton Mather suggested the school change its name to "Yale College".

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight Parkour is the sport of running an obstacle course through the built environment, usually in a city. Combining running, jumping and gymnastics to weave through alleys and fences and launch off from monuments and buildings. Like the chase scenes you sometimes see in movies. ad absurdum is riffing off the "our" spelling of parkour, but it actually comes from French. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parkour
